content.raw: The scrolling issues are mainly due to the list of visuals or collisions inside the Visuals/Collisions tabs, which uses a `QTreeWidget`, which has some confusing scrolling.
content.html: The scrolling issues are mainly due to the list of visuals or collisions inside the Visuals/Collisions tabs, which uses a QTreeWidget, which has some confusing scrolling.

content.raw: It's a bit tangential, but I noticed #1594 while testing this PR. You could add an extra warning to the collision/visual delete message if the user is trying to delete the last element to work around it. For example, if the user is deleting the only collision element, warn them that the link will not collide with anything (including the ground plane), or if they are deleting the only visual, warn them that the link will be invisible.
content.html: It's a bit tangential, but I noticed #1594 while testing this PR. You could add an extra warning to the collision/visual delete message if the user is trying to delete the last element to work around it. For example, if the user is deleting the only collision element, warn them that the link will not collide with anything (including the ground plane), or if they are deleting the only visual, warn them that the link will be invisible.

content.raw:
+1, I am not able to see all link properties unless I resize the inspector. I also seem to see two scrollbars when the inspector is small, which is confusing.

It might be related to tabs, since I have scrolling issues in the link inspector, not the joint inspector.
content.html:
+1, I am not able to see all link properties unless I resize the inspector. I also seem to see two scrollbars when the inspector is small, which is confusing.

It might be related to tabs, since I have scrolling issues in the link inspector, not the joint inspector.

content.raw: See the comment regarding x, y, z
content.html: See the comment regarding x, y, z

content.raw:
So the way I was using the tooltips was not to show an explanation of the field but to give its actual SDF tag. Mostly thinking about things like `self_collide`, which have the label `Self collide` on the inspector. 

I realize now that vectors and poses don't have SDF tags for each individual field though, so the logic I was following doesn't apply. Still, I think it might be weird that only these fields have explanatory tooltips...?
content.html:
So the way I was using the tooltips was not to show an explanation of the field but to give its actual SDF tag. Mostly thinking about things like self_collide, which have the label Self collide on the inspector.

I realize now that vectors and poses don't have SDF tags for each individual field though, so the logic I was following doesn't apply. Still, I think it might be weird that only these fields have explanatory tooltips...?

content.raw: `Size along the X axis`. Same for `y` and `z`.
content.html: Size along the X axis. Same for y and z.

content.raw: Should the tool tips for these be "red", "green", "blue", "alpha"?
content.html: Should the tool tips for these be "red", "green", "blue", "alpha"?

content.raw: Pass `_min` and `_max` by reference instead of pointer.
content.html: Pass _min and _max by reference instead of pointer.

content.raw: looks good, just the scroll area issue left that can be addressed later - ticketed issue #1577
content.html: looks good, just the scroll area issue left that can be addressed later - ticketed issue #1577

content.raw:
give default level for these `Create*Widget` functions? 

`int _level = 0`
I see that some hex color codes are repeated in different places, e.g. #999999, #d42b2b, etc. Maybe we can place them in variables in a common place so that later it's easier to customize them?
content.html: I see that some hex color codes are repeated in different places, e.g. #999999, #d42b2b, etc. Maybe we can place them in variables in a common place so that later it's easier to customize them?

content.raw: same applies to a few other places in the class that does this
content.html: same applies to a few other places in the class that does this

maybe just: 

double min = 0;
double max = 0;
valueSpinBox->setRange(&min, &max);

so we don't need to delete them

content.raw: not sure why I had -1e12 to 1e12 before. We could probably just use -/+`GZ_DBL_MAX`
content.html: not sure why I had -1e12 to 1e12 before. We could probably just use -/+GZ_DBL_MAX
